data.title: Pi of pie
data.statement:
You enter a bakery craving a slice of pie, but you want to make sure you'll get your moneys worth. In order to ensure this, you observe the slices they serve to other customers. Each slice is created by cutting twice into a fresh pie, from the middle to the edge, and taking out the piece in between the two cuts. You make note of the angle each cut is made at (0° being towards where you're standing). Using these angles along with the radius and height of the pie, you calculate exactly how much pie goes into each slice. 

For this exercise, use {{pi}} = 3.14
data.stubGenerator:
read h:int
read r:int
read s1:int
read s2:int

write 0.0
data.inputDescription:
[[h]]: An {{integer}} showing the height of the pie
[[r]]: An {{integer}} showing the radius of the pie
[[i1]]: An {{integer}} showing the degrees of where the first cut was made
[[i2]]: An {{integer}} showing the degrees of where the second cut was made
data.outputDescription:
A single number [[N]] showing the volume of the given slice of pie, accurate to one decimal.

The slice you get will always be the smallest of the two slices created (cutting two thirds out of the pie means you get one third).

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You enter a bakery craving a slice of pie, but you want to make sure you'll get your moneys worth. In order to ensure this, you observe the slices they serve to other customers. Each slice is created by cutting twice into a fresh pie, from the middle to the edge, and taking out the piece in between the two cuts. You make note of the angle each cut is made at (0° being towards where you're standing). Using these angles along with the radius and height of the pie, you calculate exactly how much pie goes into each slice.

For this exercise, use pi = 3.14
Input
h: An integer showing the height of the pie
r: An integer showing the radius of the pie
i1: An integer showing the degrees of where the first cut was made
i2: An integer showing the degrees of where the second cut was made
Output
A single number N showing the volume of the given slice of pie, accurate to one decimal.

The slice you get will always be the smallest of the two slices created (cutting two thirds out of the pie means you get one third).
Constraints
0 ≤ h ≤ 100
0 ≤ r ≤ 100
0 ≤ i1 ≤ 359
0 ≤ i2 ≤ 359

0 ≤ N ≤ 10 000
Example
Input
1
10
0
45
Output
39.3
